content.question: A curve in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane is defined by <math alttext="open parenthesis, x of t, comma y of t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x of t, equals, t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t, equals, t to the fourth power, plus 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is <math alttext="the second derivative of y, with respect to x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="the fraction with numerator negative 1, and denominator 2 times t to the fourth power, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.2: (BC ONLY) Second Derivatives of Parametric Equations

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
